results.title: L'homme de Neandertal
results.brief_description:
Episode 2 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).This episode takes us among a tribe of hunters and gatherers to find out more about their tool making techniques. We also discover how their society is affected by the Ice Age.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: L'homme Au Chapeau Rond
results.brief_description:
When his wife Nathalie dies, Nicolas, a former judge, hits the bottle. His mood becomes even grimmer when he learns that his daughter Lisa is in fact the result of Nathalie’s affair with Michel. One night, Nicolas approaches Michel with his revelations and Michel promises to look after the child. But soon after the child is despatched to the country and the two men resume their favorite game: womanising.

Credits: Director, Pierre Billon ; writers, Charles Spaak, Pierre Brive ; photography, Nicolas Toporkoff ; music, Maurice Thiriet ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch.
Cast: Raimu, Aime Clariond, Lucy Valnor, Gisele Casadessus, Louis Seigner, Jane Marken, Micheline Boudet, France Delahalle.

results.title: L'homme a la Pipe = Man with the Pipe
results.brief_description:
Documentary on 19th century French painter, Gustave Courbet.

Credits: Director, Roger Leenhardt ; photography, Georges Lendi ; music, Jean Wiener.

results.title: L'heritier = the Heir
results.brief_description:
Bart Cordell inherits his father’s business following his father’s accidental death. Bart is convinced the circumstances of this death were dubious and may be part of a ploy to destabilise his financial empire. He hires a private detective and finds that a reporter working for his father’s magazine (one of the many companies he owned) was looking into plans by another multinational to take over the company. Cordell also discovers that his father-in-law, a former Italian fascist, may not have given up his old loyalties.

Credits: Producer, Jacques-Eric Strauss ; director, Philippe Labro ; writers, Jacques Lanzmann, Philippe Labro ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Michel Colombier ; art direction, Theobald Meurisse.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Carla Gravina, Jean Rochefort, Charles Denner, Maureen Kerwin.

results.title: L'europe de L'an Mil = Europe in Year 1000
results.brief_description:
Europe in year 1000 is a wild and hungry world. Fields with poor yield are cultivated by slave labour, toiling in exchange for the protection of a local noble man. This period of history is still dominated by the figure of Charlemagne, emperor and divinity, intermediary bewteen heaven and earth, the visible and the invisible. The Palatine Chapel in Aachen (Germany), an octogonal building modelled on a Byzantine church, was to be his final resting place in 814. It remains a potent symbol of the wealth and power of the Carolingian dynasty. The influence of Byzantine art in Roman imperial art is also illustrated with the example of San Pedro de Roda (Spain). Other main works profiled in this first episode include: Tournus (Burgundy), the Bayeux tapestry, monastries of Reichenau, Echternach, Bamberg, Hildesheim and Liege.

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: L'etrange Monsieur Victor = the Strange Mr. Victor
results.creator_credit: Raoul Ploquin, Albert Valentin and Jean Gremillon
results.brief_description:
A respectable businessman during the day, Monsieur Victor is also the boss of gang of thieves. When a blackmailer threatens to reveal the true nature of his business, Monsieur Victor kills him with a tool belonging to his neighbour, Bastien Robineau. Bastien is found guilty and condemned to seven years of hard labour. Seven years later, Bastien comes back to town to seek revenge. ‘Monsieur Victor’ was partially financed by the German company UFA. The exteriors were shot in Toulon (South of France) and the interiors at the Babelsberg studios in Berlin. The film had no success when released in 1938. Raoul Ploquin, the producer, took the initiative to re-issue the film in 1974, after lengthy research in various cinematheques. The film was then hailed as one of Gremillon’s finest work.

Credits: Producer, Raoul Ploquin, Albert Valentin ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writers, Marcel Achard, Charles Spaak ; photography, Werner Krien ; music, Roland Manuel.
Cast: Raimu, Madeleine Renaud, Pierre Blanchar, Marcelle Geniat, Andrex, Viviane Romance, Marcel Maupi.

results.title: L'etoile du Nord = the North Star
results.creator_credit: WDR La Sept Cinema and Pierre Granier-Deferre
results.brief_description:
After years of aimlessly wandering around Northern Africa, Edouard Binet is sailing back to Europe. On board, he encounters the beautiful Sylvie and introduces her to Nemrod, a successful merchant, who is carrying a valuable jewel. After disembarking, Edouard accepts Sylvie’s offer to stay at her mother’s pension in Belgium. At the pension, Edouard’s charm endears him to Sylvie’s aging, lonely mother, Madame Baron. The stories of his fabulous adventures do much to ease her ennui. When they read in the papers that Nemrod has been murdered during a train trip to Paris and his valuable gem stolen, Sylvie begins to suspect that Edouard may have had something to do with Nemrod’s death. Awards: French Academy of Cinema: Best Supporting Actress: Fanny Cottencon; Best Writing - Adaptation: Jean Aurenche, Pierre Granier-Deferre, Michel Grisolia.

Credits: Producer, Alain Sarde ; director, Pierre Granier-Deferre ; writers, Pierre Granier-Deferre, Jean Aurenche, Michel Grisolia ; photography, Pierre-William Glenn ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Simone Signoret, Philippe Noiret, Fanny Cottencon, Julie Jezequel, Jean Rougerie.

results.title: L'eternel Evade = the Elusive Prisoner
results.brief_description:
Inspector Flambart is escorting a chain of convicts taking Vidocq back to the prison for the fourth time. Vidocq and his two accomplices manage to break away from the chain gang. Flambart immediadelity launches the chase to re-capture them, but Vidocq has found a safe haven with a most welcoming milkmaid.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Jacques Seiler, Mario David.

results.title: L'enfant Invisible = the Invisible Child
results.brief_description:
A young boy is enjoying a pleasant holiday in a beautiful villa by the sea. One day, he meets a young transparent girl, who only he can see and starts playing with her.

Credits: Director: Andre Lindon ; writer, Andre Lindon ; music, Ronan Girre, Jean-Jacques Rulhmann ; animators, Andre Lindon, Muriel Petit, Mickael Volaris.

results.title: L'enfance Nue = Nude Childhood
results.creator_credit: Claude Berri, Mag Bodard, Francois Truffaut and Maurice Pialat
results.brief_description:
Ten year old Francois, abandonned by his mother, is sent to a working-class foster family where his behaviour becomes rather disturbing. After several incidents, he is sent to an other family. The parents are elderly, the grandmother ancient and a foster brother awkward and shy. The placement proves a success, although it eventually leads to a crisis. After a decade in televison, Pialat made his directorial debut with a New Wave style drama of adolescence featuring a cast of non-professional players. Such films, ten years after the arrival of the ‘nouvelle vague’, had become a kind of recognized genre unto themselves rather than a striking gesture of independence from established norms, and it is not surprising that Pialat’s work often led him in other directions. Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992. Awards: Prix Jean Vigo 1969.

Credits: Producers, Claude Berri, Mag Bodard, Francois Truffaut ; director, Maurice Pialat ; writers, Maurice Pialat, Arlette Langman ; photography, Claude Beausoleil.
Cast: Michel Tarrazon, Linda Gutemberg, Raoul Billerey, Pierrette Delplanque.
